newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: GENCOR SAYS SEES MOZAL DECISION THIS MONTH.
newsitem.headline: GENCOR SAYS SEES MOZAL DECISION THIS MONTH.

text.p: South African mining house Gencor ltd said on Wednesday it expected to make a decision by the end of this month on whether to begin construction of the $1.25 billion Mozal aluminium smelter in Mozambique.
"The project team has got very far along the way with their studies so that decision is now imminent," chairman Brian Gilbertson told Reuters.
"I suspect that you will see an answer quite soon," he added.
He declined to say whether or not he expected the board to approve the project.
The company earlier said it planned to spin off its non-precious metal assets into a U.K.-based firm, Billiton Plc, and use it raise $1 billion from international equity markets.
Gilbertson said the Mozambique project was one of several possible applications for the funds raised.
Alusaf Ltd, a Gencor unit, said in April construction of the smelter could begin in October for completion in August 2000.
Gilbertson said the investment, should it be approved, would easily be the biggest made by a private sector company in the Mozambican economy.

He said the smelter was likely to produce in excess of 233,000 tonnes of aluminium a year, should it match the performance of Alusaf's Richard's Bay operations which run at about 107 percent of design capacity.
"The design capacity of a single line -- and this is a single line -- is 233,000 tonnes a year"
"I think we'll get 230,000 to 250,000 tonnes depending on how well the process works," he said.
